elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ⋅ A new tetrameric ligand (TBTP) was synthesized using click chemistry strategy.   ⋅ Copper(II) with TBTP form 1-D coordination polymer.   ⋅ 1-D coordination polymers present antiferromagnetic behavior.   ⋅ Oxidation of aniline to azobenzene is catalyzed by the 1D coordination polymer.

<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:link id="lk00035" locator="ga1" xlink:href="pii:S0020169318318176/ga1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A new tetrameric ligand (TBTP) was synthesized using click chemistry strategy.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Copper(II) with TBTP form 1-D coordination polymer.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">1-D coordination polymers present antiferromagnetic behavior.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Oxidation of aniline to azobenzene is catalyzed by the 1D coordination polymer.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A novel tetrameric tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol (TBTP) has been synthesized using click chemistry strategy. TBTP was characterized and used as ligand to form new Cu(II) complexes, forming 1-D coordination polymers. Two square planar complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, presenting formula [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu(TBTP)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). In both structures, a cationic 1-D coordination polymer (CP) has been formed. The CP contain a 1:1 Cu(II)/TBTP ratio with four neutral triazole groups coordinating the Cu(II) center, forming a Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds ranging 1.988(2)–2.001(2) Å. The study of the magnetic properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> pointed to an antiferromagnetic behavior for both compounds, defined by inter- and intra-chain dipolar interactions among their metallic centers. In addition, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was found to be an efficient catalyst for selective oxidation of aniline to azobenzene under mild reaction conditions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
A new tetrameric ligand (TBTP) was synthesized using click chemistry strategy.

Copper(II) with TBTP form 1-D coordination polymer.

1-D coordination polymers present antiferromagnetic behavior.

Oxidation of aniline to azobenzene is catalyzed by the 1D coordination polymer.

Abstract

A novel tetrameric tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol (TBTP) has been synthesized using click chemistry strategy. TBTP was characterized and used as ligand to form new Cu(II) complexes, forming 1-D coordination polymers. Two square planar complexes were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, presenting formula [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(NO3)4] (1) and [Cu(TBTP)](NO3)2 (2). In both structures, a cationic 1-D coordination polymer (CP) has been formed. The CP contain a 1:1 Cu(II)/TBTP ratio with four neutral triazole groups coordinating the Cu(II) center, forming a CuN bonds ranging 1.988(2)-2.001(2)Å. The study of the magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 pointed to an antiferromagnetic behavior for both compounds, defined by inter- and intra-chain dipolar interactions among their metallic centers. In addition, the complex 1 was found to be an efficient catalyst for selective oxidation of aniline to azobenzene under mild reaction conditions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Since the nineteenth century, the study of coordination compounds has been a great challenge for inorganic chemists. This class of compounds highlights the relevance of this type of chemistry in drug development, chemosensors, molecular magnets, electrochemical and photochemical studies, supramolecular chemistry, catalysis, technological and environmental applications .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Since the nineteenth century, the study of coordination compounds has been a great challenge for inorganic chemists. This class of compounds highlights the relevance of this type of chemistry in drug development, chemosensors, molecular magnets, electrochemical and photochemical studies, supramolecular chemistry, catalysis, technological and environmental applications .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Recently, many studies have focus on synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CP) based on copper metal in order to better understand and to explore their intriguing structural properties and several important application such as luminescent, catalytic and magnetic properties, attributed to Cu(I) and Cu(II) polymers, respectively .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Recently, many studies have focus on synthesis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CP) based on copper metal in order to better understand and to explore their intriguing structural properties and several important application such as luminescent, catalytic and magnetic properties, attributed to Cu(I) and Cu(II) polymers, respectively .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Currently, the reported works presenting coordination compounds based on triazoles have shown the great interest of researchers for the remarkable properties that these compounds may display . Triazole rings can act as ligands for complexation due to the electron donor capacity of the nitrogen atoms constituting the triazole ring. This feature makes them an important tool in coordination chemistry for the synthesis of new compound . Based on this aspects, the development of coordination compounds derived from ligands based on 1,2,3-triazole has opened a new area of inorganic synthesis to construct useful compounds with a large variety of interesting applications, with can include magnetic and catalytic properties.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Currently, the reported works presenting coordination compounds based on triazoles have shown the great interest of researchers for the remarkable properties that these compounds may display . Triazole rings can act as ligands for complexation due to the electron donor capacity of the nitrogen atoms constituting the triazole ring. This feature makes them an important tool in coordination chemistry for the synthesis of new compound . Based on this aspects, the development of coordination compounds derived from ligands based on 1,2,3-triazole has opened a new area of inorganic synthesis to construct useful compounds with a large variety of interesting applications, with can include magnetic and catalytic properties.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The magnetic properties of polynuclear coordination compounds are studied with the objective to evaluate the magnitude of the interaction between the metallic centers. Therefore, a recent strategy that can be used to obtain magnetic systems is the use of dendrimeric ligands containing multiple coordination sites .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of polynuclear coordination compounds are studied with the objective to evaluate the magnitude of the interaction between the metallic centers. Therefore, a recent strategy that can be used to obtain magnetic systems is the use of dendrimeric ligands containing multiple coordination sites .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">As part of our ongoing focus on dendrimeric systems, in this study, we have synthesized a novel tetrameric ligand based on 1,2,3-triazoles from click chemistry approach, and we have evaluated its reactivity with copper(II) ion. The single-crystal X-ray structure, molecular conformation and the potential magnetic and catalytic properties of Cu(II)-based complex on the aniline oxidation, using hydrogen peroxide as oxidizing agent, have been studied. The oxidation of aniline to produce azobenzene is an important reaction since azo compounds are valuable inputs widely employed in industry . At the same time, the selective aniline conversion to azobenzene is a challenging reaction for catalysis due to the possibility of multiple oxidized derivatives, such as, nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene . Besides, there are few reports describing the oxidation of aniline with hydrogen peroxide, leading mainly to azobenzene, promoted by metal-ligand complexes .</ce:para>

At the same time, the selective aniline conversion to azobenzene is a challenging reaction for catalysis due to the possibility of multiple oxidized derivatives, such as, nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene . Besides, there are few reports describing the oxidation of aniline with hydrogen peroxide, leading mainly to azobenzene, promoted by metal-ligand complexes .

<ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">All reagents and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and utilized without previous purification. Silica gel 60 (0.063–0.200 mm) from Merck was employed for column chromatography. Plates of silica gel with fluorescence indicator were employed for thin layer chromatography using anisaldehyde ethanolic solution potassium permanganate alkaline solution or aqueous mostain solution as revealers. Sephadex LH20 (Pharmacia) and Sephadex G15 (Aldrich) were utilized for size exclusion chromatography. The eluent composition used is detailed in each case. Ultrafree-MC tubes 0.1 μm (Millipore) were used for filtration through centrifugation. Yields refer to chromatographically and spectroscopically pure materials, unless otherwise stated. <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR and <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR were recorded on either Bruker 300 (<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR-300 MHz; <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR 75 MHz) or Bruker 400 (<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR-400 MHz; <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR-100 MHz) or Bruker 500 (<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR-500 MHz; <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR-125 MHz) at ambient temperature using CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OD and DMSO‑<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> as solvents. Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million relative to residual protic solvent internal standard or TMS. Data for <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift, integration, multiplicity (s = singlet, m = multiplet) and coupling constants in Hertz. All <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR spectra were recorded with complete proton decoupling. Elemental analyses were carried out using a LECO Tru-Spec CHN analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Varian 640 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Mass spectra (MS) were obtained on an Esquire 6000 Bruker Daltonics (EM-ESI) by electrospray ionization. The fusion rates were determined in Logan scientific LS-III apparatus and are not corrected. Q-band electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were recorded at different temperatures with a Bruker ER 200 spectrometer equipped with a helium continuous-flow cryostat. Direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range of 1.9–300 K under applied dc fields of 5000 G (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> ≥ 50 K) and 250 G (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> < 50 K). The experimental magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the constituent atoms and the simple holder (a plastic bag). The crystal filtration, using tubes with filtering membrane, was carried out in centrifuge Excelsa II 206 BL FANEM. The crystals were measured and photographed using optic microscope Olympus BX40. The cycloaddition reactions were carried out in a Biotage Initiator Eight microwave apparatus.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reagents and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and utilized without previous purification. Silica gel 60 (0.063-0.200mm) from Merck was employed for column chromatography. Plates of silica gel with fluorescence indicator were employed for thin layer chromatography using anisaldehyde ethanolic solution potassium permanganate alkaline solution or aqueous mostain solution as revealers. Sephadex LH20 (Pharmacia) and Sephadex G15 (Aldrich) were utilized for size exclusion chromatography. The eluent composition used is detailed in each case. Ultrafree-MC tubes 0.1μm (Millipore) were used for filtration through centrifugation. Yields refer to chromatographically and spectroscopically pure materials, unless otherwise stated. 1H NMR and 13C NMR were recorded on either Bruker 300 (1H NMR-300MHz; 13C NMR 75MHz) or Bruker 400 (1H NMR-400MHz; 13C NMR-100MHz) or Bruker 500 (1H NMR-500MHz; 13C NMR-125MHz) at ambient temperature using CDCl3, CD3OD and DMSO-d 6 as solvents. Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million relative to residual protic solvent internal standard or TMS. Data for 1H NMR are reported as follows: chemical shift, integration, multiplicity (s=singlet, m=multiplet) and coupling constants in Hertz. All 13C NMR spectra were recorded with complete proton decoupling. Elemental analyses were carried out using a LECO Tru-Spec CHN analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Varian 640 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Mass spectra (MS) were obtained on an Esquire 6000 Bruker Daltonics (EM-ESI) by electrospray ionization. The fusion rates were determined in Logan scientific LS-III apparatus and are not corrected. Q-band electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of polycrystalline samples of 1-2 were recorded at different temperatures with a Bruker ER 200 spectrometer equipped with a helium continuous-flow cryostat. Direct-current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed polycrystalline samples of 1-2 with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range of 1.9-300K under applied dc fields of 5000 G (T≥50K) and 250 G (T<50K). The experimental magnetic susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetic contributions of the constituent atoms and the simple holder (a plastic bag). The crystal filtration, using tubes with filtering membrane, was carried out in centrifuge Excelsa II 206 BL FANEM. The crystals were measured and photographed using optic microscope Olympus BX40. The cycloaddition reactions were carried out in a Biotage Initiator Eight microwave apparatus.

<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthetic procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:bold>Tetrakis(2-propinyloximethyl)methane</ce:bold>
 To the solution of pentaerythritol (1.087 g, 7.35 mmol) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (50 mL), cooled at 0 °C in argon atmosphere, sodium hydride 60% (1.787 g, 44.10 mmol) was added portionwise, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Propargyl bromide (3.67 mL, 41.16 mmol) was added dropwise at 0 °C. After ten minutes, the temperature was increased until room temperature and the reaction was stirred for 24 h. Then, water (100 mL) was poured and the mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3x50 mL). Combined extracts were washed with brine (3x50 mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography (hexane:EtOAc 7:3, hexane:EtOAc 7:3, potassium permanganate solution as revealer) to furnish <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as a yellow solid (1.45 mg, 63%). FT-IR <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>: 3278, 2920, 2888, 2117, 1471, 1437, 1357, 1087, 906, 686. ESI-MS calculated for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> C<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Na: 311.1[M + Na]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>; found 311.1.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">
<ce:bold>Benzylazide</ce:bold>
 Benzyl bromide (1.44 g, 8.41 mmol) and sodium azide (4.39 g, 67.28 mmol) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (40 mL) was stirred at 60 °C, for 24 h. The reaction was followed by TLC, using anisaldehyde as revealer. The mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3 × 50 mL) and combined extracts were washed with brine (2 × 30 mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated, furnishing benzylazide as a light brown liquid (859 mg, 77%). <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR (CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 300 MHz): δ 4.37 (s, 2H), δ 7.44–7.37 (m, 5H). <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR (CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 75 MHz): δ 135.8; δ 129.22; δ 128.69; δ 128.61, δ 55.17.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st050">Crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Crystals of suitable size for X-ray diffraction analysis, were coated with dry perfluoropolyether and mounted on glass fibers and fixed in a cold nitrogen stream (T = 213 K) to the goniometer head. Data collections were performed on a Bruker-Nonius X8Apex-II CCD diffractometer, using monochromatic radiation λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å, by means of ω and φ scans with a width of 0.50°. The data were reduced (SAINT)  and corrected for absorption effects by the multi-scan method (SADABS) . The structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-2002)  and refined against all <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> data by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXTL-6.12)  minimizing w[<ce:italic>F<ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
</ce:bold>]<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on the attached atoms with the isotropic temperature factors (<ce:italic>U</ce:italic>iso values) fixed at 1.2 times (1.5 times for methyl groups) those <ce:italic>U</ce:italic>eq values of the corresponding attached atoms. In the complex 1, two nitrate in the [Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion and one 1-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-benzyl group of <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> ligand are disordered in the asymmetric unit. All these disordered groups were clearly observed disordered in two positions which were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. At the end of the refinement the occupancy factors for all these disordered moieties were fixed to 0.5. Some geometric restraints (DFIX command), the ADP restraint SIMU and the rigid bond restraint DELU were used to make the geometric and ADP values of the disordered atoms more reasonable. A search for solvent-accessible voids in the crystal structure of [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) using PLATON showed a potential solvent volume of 336 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and subsequent application of SQUEEZE  procedures showed two relevant voids each with a solvent-accessible volume of 168 Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>. This procedure showed 53 electrons accessible in the voids. However, the highest peak in the difference map is significantly below 0.3 e/ Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> and as a result of that, the nature of the solvent could not be identified, not to mention a refinement. This indicates that the crystal lost nearly all of its solvent of crystallization by the time without collapse of the structure. CCDC 1811037 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) – 1811038 (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via <ce:inter-ref id="ir005" xlink:href="http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif" xlink:type="simple">www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Crystals of suitable size for X-ray diffraction analysis, were coated with dry perfluoropolyether and mounted on glass fibers and fixed in a cold nitrogen stream (T=213K) to the goniometer head. Data collections were performed on a Bruker-Nonius X8Apex-II CCD diffractometer, using monochromatic radiation λ(Mo Kα)=0.71073Å, by means of ω and φ scans with a width of 0.50°. The data were reduced (SAINT)  and corrected for absorption effects by the multi-scan method (SADABS) . The structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-2002)  and refined against all F 2 data by full-matrix least-squares techniques (SHELXTL-6.12)  minimizing w[Fo  2-F  2 ]2. All the non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to ride on the attached atoms with the isotropic temperature factors (Uiso values) fixed at 1.2 times (1.5 times for methyl groups) those Ueq values of the corresponding attached atoms. In the complex 1, two nitrate in the [Cu(η1-NO3)4]2- anion and one 1-N-benzyl group of TBTP ligand are disordered in the asymmetric unit. All these disordered groups were clearly observed disordered in two positions which were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. At the end of the refinement the occupancy factors for all these disordered moieties were fixed to 0.5. Some geometric restraints (DFIX command), the ADP restraint SIMU and the rigid bond restraint DELU were used to make the geometric and ADP values of the disordered atoms more reasonable. A search for solvent-accessible voids in the crystal structure of [Cu(TBTP)](NO3)2 (2) using PLATON showed a potential solvent volume of 336Å3 and subsequent application of SQUEEZE  procedures showed two relevant voids each with a solvent-accessible volume of 168Å3. This procedure showed 53 electrons accessible in the voids. However, the highest peak in the difference map is significantly below 0.3e/Å3 and as a result of that, the nature of the solvent could not be identified, not to mention a refinement. This indicates that the crystal lost nearly all of its solvent of crystallization by the time without collapse of the structure. CCDC 1811037 (1) - 1811038 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

<ce:section-title id="st055">Catalytic oxidation of aniline</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The aniline oxidation reaction was conducted according to the procedure previously described . In a typical experiment, a mixture of 0.1 mL of aniline (SYNTH), 0.50 mL of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (30% (w/w), Sigma-Aldrich) 10 mg of catalyst and 3 mL of solvent (acetonitrile, SYNTH) was transferred to a 10 mL round-bottom flask connected to a septum-inlet Flask. This catalytic system was kept under stirring for 12 h at room-temperature. Upon completion, the reaction was quenched. Next, an aliquot of the reaction medium was then diluted in chloroform and injected in to the gas chromatograph for analysis. The analysis was performed on gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2010 Plus Tracera) connected to a Shimadzu SH-Rtx-5 capillary column and barrier discharge ionization detector (BID). Aniline conversion and product formation were quantified with the help of an external calibration curve, which was obtained by injecting authentic samples of known concentrations. elements.clean_text:
Catalytic oxidation of aniline

The aniline oxidation reaction was conducted according to the procedure previously described . In a typical experiment, a mixture of 0.1mL of aniline (SYNTH), 0.50mL of H2O2 (30% (w/w), Sigma-Aldrich) 10mg of catalyst and 3mL of solvent (acetonitrile, SYNTH) was transferred to a 10mL round-bottom flask connected to a septum-inlet Flask. This catalytic system was kept under stirring for 12h at room-temperature. Upon completion, the reaction was quenched. Next, an aliquot of the reaction medium was then diluted in chloroform and injected in to the gas chromatograph for analysis. The analysis was performed on gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2010 Plus Tracera) connected to a Shimadzu SH-Rtx-5 capillary column and barrier discharge ionization detector (BID). Aniline conversion and product formation were quantified with the help of an external calibration curve, which was obtained by injecting authentic samples of known concentrations. Conversion of aniline was calculated by Eq. :  (1)   Conversion   ( % )   =    moles of reactant reacted   initial moles of reactant used   × 100

<ce:section-title id="st060">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st065">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The ligand tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol (TBTP) was synthesized using the previously described tetralkyne and benzylazide through Cu(I) catalyzed azides and alkynes cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction, a classic Click Chemistry reaction (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis

The ligand tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol (TBTP) was synthesized using the previously described tetralkyne and benzylazide through Cu(I) catalyzed azides and alkynes cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction, a classic Click Chemistry reaction ( ) .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0100" view="all">The complexation between the tetrameric ligand (<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>) and copper (II) metal [Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] provided two different coordination compounds, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, depending of the experimental conditions used. Acetonitrile or a mixture of acetonitrile/water was used as solvents to obtain compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. Initially, solubility tests at room temperature with <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> and Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were performed to identify the best solvent to be used. Among the solvents considered, DMF, with a relatively high dielectric constant (ε = 37) was the only one capable of solubilizing both the ligand <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> as well as the copper salt Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at room temperature. However, the formation of the complex [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> was not observed in DMF. Thus, acetonitrile (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN) was the most appropriate solvent and the minimum temperature for complete solubilisation of the <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> in this solvent was 45 °C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The complexation between the tetrameric ligand (TBTP) and copper (II) metal [Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O] provided two different coordination compounds, 1 and 2, depending of the experimental conditions used. Acetonitrile or a mixture of acetonitrile/water was used as solvents to obtain compounds 1 or 2, respectively. Initially, solubility tests at room temperature with TBTP and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O were performed to identify the best solvent to be used. Among the solvents considered, DMF, with a relatively high dielectric constant (ε=37) was the only one capable of solubilizing both the ligand TBTP as well as the copper salt Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O at room temperature. However, the formation of the complex [Cu(TBTP)]2+ was not observed in DMF. Thus, acetonitrile (CH3CN) was the most appropriate solvent and the minimum temperature for complete solubilisation of the TBTP in this solvent was 45°C.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0105" view="all">The choice of the copper salt used to obtain the complex was based on empirical test. Several salts were selected; however, only the complexation between the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions from Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and the ligand <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> was favorable for obtaining single crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The choice of the copper salt used to obtain the complex was based on empirical test. Several salts were selected; however, only the complexation between the Cu2+ ions from Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, and the ligand TBTP was favorable for obtaining single crystals of compound 1 and 2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0110" view="all">To obtain the solid <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the stoichiometric ratio between <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> and Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was 1:1. The solubilisation of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in acetonitrile led to a clear blue solution due to the possible formation of the complex [Cu(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>. The addition of <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> to this solution at 45 °C induced the color change to a dark blue solution, corresponding to the formation of the complex [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis. When eight drops of water is added in the mixture was obtained de complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To obtain the solid 1 or 2, the stoichiometric ratio between TBTP and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O was 1:1. The solubilisation of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O in acetonitrile led to a clear blue solution due to the possible formation of the complex [Cu(CH3CN)4]2+. The addition of TBTP to this solution at 45°C induced the color change to a dark blue solution, corresponding to the formation of the complex [Cu(TBTP)]2+, confirmed by X-ray diffraction analysis. When eight drops of water is added in the mixture was obtained de complex 2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0115" view="all">In an attempt to increase the yield to obtain the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a reaction was performed using of 2:1 (metal:ligand) ratio of Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>. However, there not was an increase in yield neither a difference in the crystal structure of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In an attempt to increase the yield to obtain the complex 1, a reaction was performed using of 2:1 (metal:ligand) ratio of Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O and TBTP. However, there not was an increase in yield neither a difference in the crystal structure of the compound 1 was observed.

elements.content:

Each of these rings has a nitrogen atom electron donor available to coordinate with the copper(II) ion. The reaction of formation of the complex [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> likely occurs by replacing the CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules by the triazoles of the tetrameric molecule (<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>), stabilized by the chelate effect, according Eq. :<ce:display>

elements.clean_text: The ligand TBTP shows four coordination sites corresponding to the tetrameric presentation of the four 1,2,3-triazole present in the molecule. Each of these rings has a nitrogen atom electron donor available to coordinate with the copper(II) ion. The reaction of formation of the complex [Cu(TBTP)]2+ likely occurs by replacing the CH3CN molecules by the triazoles of the tetrameric molecule (TBTP), stabilized by the chelate effect, according Eq. :  (3)        Cu       CH 3  CN     4       2 +   + TBTP →       Cu    TBTP         2 +   +  4    CH  3  CN

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">To confirm the structure of these complexes, single crystals of coordination compounds described in this work were obtained using the crystallization techniques by slow diffusion and slow evaporation. However, the later one proved to be the best to obtain good quality single crystals of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To confirm the structure of these complexes, single crystals of coordination compounds described in this work were obtained using the crystallization techniques by slow diffusion and slow evaporation. However, the later one proved to be the best to obtain good quality single crystals of the 1 and 2 ().

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st070">Description of the crystal structures 1 and 2</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The two copper compounds, [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu(TBTP)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), derived from copper nitrate and the TBTP ligand, crystallize in the monoclinic system, in the space groups <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of the crystal structures 1 and 2

The two copper compounds, [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(η1-NO3)4] (1) and [Cu(TBTP)](NO3)2 (2), derived from copper nitrate and the TBTP ligand, crystallize in the monoclinic system, in the space groups P2/c and P21/c respectively ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">Both complexes appear in its crystal structure with a similar polynuclear one-dimensional cationic chain, whereas they present very different counter-anions, depending upon the solvent used in the formation of the complexes. The asymmetric unit of 1, as derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, can be visualized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a. Due to similarity with 1, the crystal structure of the complex 2 is represented in the . The bond and angle lengths determined experimentally for 1 and 2 agree well with the average query analyzed by MOGUL . For the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C aromatic rings all values are close to expected value at around 1.38(2) Å. In the triazole rings, the N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond length is ranging 1.313–1.332 Å, while the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are slightly larger (1.336–1.358 Å). The coordination of copper did not affect significantly the N<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N and C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Both complexes appear in its crystal structure with a similar polynuclear one-dimensional cationic chain, whereas they present very different counter-anions, depending upon the solvent used in the formation of the complexes. The asymmetric unit of 1, as derived from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, can be visualized in  a. Due to similarity with 1, the crystal structure of the complex 2 is represented in the . The bond and angle lengths determined experimentally for 1 and 2 agree well with the average query analyzed by MOGUL . For the CC aromatic rings all values are close to expected value at around 1.38(2) Å. In the triazole rings, the NN bond length is ranging 1.313-1.332Å, while the CN bond lengths are slightly larger (1.336-1.358Å). The coordination of copper did not affect significantly the NN and CN bond.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">The cationic polynuclear chains are formed by alternate units of copper ions bridged by the tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol, <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> ligand, in such a way that the metal atoms and the quaternary carbons of the pentaerythritol moieties are centred on the axis of the one-dimensional chain. These tetratopic linkers connect the metals through a double-bridge configuration on each side; thereby, bidentate <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> ligand coordinates to each of the two adjacent copper ions that flank it by a couple of triazole nitrogen groups <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-bounded to metal.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The cationic polynuclear chains are formed by alternate units of copper ions bridged by the tetra[O-((1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl)]-pentaerythritol, TBTP ligand, in such a way that the metal atoms and the quaternary carbons of the pentaerythritol moieties are centred on the axis of the one-dimensional chain. These tetratopic linkers connect the metals through a double-bridge configuration on each side; thereby, bidentate TBTP ligand coordinates to each of the two adjacent copper ions that flank it by a couple of triazole nitrogen groups trans-bounded to metal.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0145" view="all">In turn, the Cu(II) self-select a square-planar geometry with double <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-triazole groups at the 3-position coordination, in such a way that each of the pairs of <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-triazole groups belong to each of the two tetratopic linkers <ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold> that flank it. All the Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths lie in the range from 1.998(6) to 2.001(5) Å, for both cationic polymers. This provides a simple and straight-forward coordination mode for the spacer to support 1D polymer chains. The coordination polymers spreading along the crystallographic <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis for [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and along the <ce:italic>b-</ce:italic>axis for [Cu(<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>)][Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>, matching for this latter complex with a binary rotation axis of the space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>. Therefore, the asymmetric unit that appears for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is only one-half, generating the rest of it by symmetry (a). The molecular conformation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are very similar, presenting the main differences on the 1-<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-benzyl triazole groups conformation, as can be seen by the overlap between the both structures (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In turn, the Cu(II) self-select a square-planar geometry with double trans-triazole groups at the 3-position coordination, in such a way that each of the pairs of trans-triazole groups belong to each of the two tetratopic linkers TBTP that flank it. All the CuN bond lengths lie in the range from 1.998(6) to 2.001(5)Å, for both cationic polymers. This provides a simple and straight-forward coordination mode for the spacer to support 1D polymer chains. The coordination polymers spreading along the crystallographic a-axis for [Cu(TBTP)](NO3)2 (2) and along the b-axis for [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(η1-NO3)4] (1), matching for this latter complex with a binary rotation axis of the space group P2/c. Therefore, the asymmetric unit that appears for 1 and 2 is only one-half, generating the rest of it by symmetry (a). The molecular conformation of 1 and 2 are very similar, presenting the main differences on the 1-N-benzyl triazole groups conformation, as can be seen by the overlap between the both structures (b).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0150" view="all">The similarity can be also emphasized by the dihedral angle between the least-squares planes through the two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-triazole rings, presenting the value of 74.25° and 75.55 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. When we analyze the Cu…Cu distance occurring in each 1D-coordiantion polymer, in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is observed the Cu1…Cu1 separation of 8.860 Å, while in the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the Cu1..Cu1 distance is slightly shorter (8.630 Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The similarity can be also emphasized by the dihedral angle between the least-squares planes through the two trans-triazole rings, presenting the value of 74.25° and 75.55 for 1 and 2, respectively. When we analyze the Cu…Cu distance occurring in each 1D-coordiantion polymer, in 2 is observed the Cu1…Cu1 separation of 8.860Å, while in the structure of 1 the Cu1..Cu1 distance is slightly shorter (8.630Å).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0155" view="all">The crystal packing of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>) is stabilized mainly by weak intermolecular interactions that were better explored using the 2-D fingerprint plot of the Hirshfeld surface. Such as observed to intermolecular contacts, the shortest distribution points (∼1.05 Å) occur due to H…H contacts that present the biggest contribution to stabilize the crystal packing presenting 36,3% in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 46,9% in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Also, the fingerprint plots present non-classical H…O intermolecular contacts between the C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H groups of the complex and oxygen atoms of nitrate with contribution of 24.8% and 19.1% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. Such as expected the greater contrition occurs in the solid containing the [Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion that presents four nitrate, while the solid <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> presents only two nitrate anions per asymmetric unit.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The crystal packing of 1 and 2 ( ) is stabilized mainly by weak intermolecular interactions that were better explored using the 2-D fingerprint plot of the Hirshfeld surface. Such as observed to intermolecular contacts, the shortest distribution points (~1.05Å) occur due to H…H contacts that present the biggest contribution to stabilize the crystal packing presenting 36,3% in 1 and 46,9% in 2. Also, the fingerprint plots present non-classical H…O intermolecular contacts between the CH groups of the complex and oxygen atoms of nitrate with contribution of 24.8% and 19.1% for 1 and 2, respectively. Such as expected the greater contrition occurs in the solid containing the [Cu(η1-NO3)4] 2  - anion that presents four nitrate, while the solid 2 presents only two nitrate anions per asymmetric unit.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0160" view="all">Analyzing the crystal self-assembly of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counter-anions consist of two units of discrete nitrate anions by each of copper present in the cationic polymer chain. The NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions are surrounding the 1-D polymer such as illustrated in the . Nevertheless, in the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, counter-ion forms one unit of tetranitrocuprate [Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion by each of copper present in the cationic polymer chain. The voluminous [Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> distort the Hirshfeld surface more than the NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The structure of the [Cu(η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion presents a square-planar coordinated with four monodentate nitrates groups, in which two of them appear disordered. The disordered groups were modeled each on two positions whose occupation coefficients were fixed to 0.5 for both at the end of refinement. The Cu-O distances ranging from 1.78(2) to 2.08(2) Å, although the nitrate groups also make weaker contacts to the copper through a second oxygen atom (ca. 2.67 Å). This is similar to other structures that contain this tetranitrocuprate , assessing the error involved in the disorder observed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Analyzing the crystal self-assembly of 2, the NO3 - counter-anions consist of two units of discrete nitrate anions by each of copper present in the cationic polymer chain. The NO3 - anions are surrounding the 1-D polymer such as illustrated in the . Nevertheless, in the complex 1, counter-ion forms one unit of tetranitrocuprate [Cu(NO3)4]2- anion by each of copper present in the cationic polymer chain. The voluminous [Cu(η1-NO3)4] 2  - distort the Hirshfeld surface more than the NO3 - ( ). The structure of the [Cu(η1-NO3)4] 2  - anion presents a square-planar coordinated with four monodentate nitrates groups, in which two of them appear disordered. The disordered groups were modeled each on two positions whose occupation coefficients were fixed to 0.5 for both at the end of refinement. The Cu-O distances ranging from 1.78(2) to 2.08(2)Å, although the nitrate groups also make weaker contacts to the copper through a second oxygen atom (ca. 2.67Å). This is similar to other structures that contain this tetranitrocuprate , assessing the error involved in the disorder observed.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0165" view="all">In both crystal structures, the anions are placed between the cationic polymeric chains helping to preserve the electrostatic stability of frameworks and this way the structural integrity of crystals. The adjacent cationic one-dimensional chains are staked in an offset face-to-face fashion and an edge-to-face fashion with the shortest contact widespread between ca. 3.468 and 4.377 Å. These weak intermolecular aromatic interactions help to arrange the one-dimensional cationic chains into a three-dimensional array.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st080">Catalytic properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0185" view="all">In order to probe the catalytic activity of the synthesized 1-D coordination polymer, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was used as catalyst for aniline oxidation reaction under mild conditions (room temperature, atmospheric pressure and using H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as oxidizing agent). Previously, the reaction was conducted without catalyst under the same conditions. No appreciable aniline conversion was detected in this case. However, by using the coordination polymer, it could be observed that the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was very active (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>), practically promoting the complete conversion of aniline (91.9%). Regarding the reaction selectivity, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> preferentially catalyzed the formation of azobenzene (45.9% of selectivity), with some concomitant formation of nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene as secondary products. The phenylhydroxylamine production was not detected. This result indicates that phenylhydroxylamine oxidizes to nitrosobenzene and further to nitrobenzene. In the course of the reaction, however, intermediate phenylhydroxylamine can react with aniline or nitrosobenzene to form azobenzene or azoxybenzene and the unconverted aniline can also react with nitrosobenzene by condensation to form azobenzene, which can also be oxidized to form azoxybenzene (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) . In order to further examine the catalytic properties, we have investigated the conversion for the oxidation of aniline and the products selectivity, using only Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as catalyst under the same reaction conditions. The result showed that the Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> led to a much lower aniline conversion (about 12%) relative to the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> catalyst displayed curious behavior in terms of selectivity, leading to the preferentially formation of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-phenylformamide (a product from the formylation of aniline) probably due to the acidity of the reaction medium, and only traces of nitrobenzene . The results highlight the superior catalytic performance of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for aniline oxidation to azobenzene compared with the Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> salt.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic properties

In order to probe the catalytic activity of the synthesized 1-D coordination polymer, the complex 1 was used as catalyst for aniline oxidation reaction under mild conditions (room temperature, atmospheric pressure and using H2O2 as oxidizing agent). Previously, the reaction was conducted without catalyst under the same conditions. No appreciable aniline conversion was detected in this case. However, by using the coordination polymer, it could be observed that the compound 1 was very active ( ), practically promoting the complete conversion of aniline (91.9%). Regarding the reaction selectivity, compound 1 preferentially catalyzed the formation of azobenzene (45.9% of selectivity), with some concomitant formation of nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene as secondary products. The phenylhydroxylamine production was not detected. This result indicates that phenylhydroxylamine oxidizes to nitrosobenzene and further to nitrobenzene. In the course of the reaction, however, intermediate phenylhydroxylamine can react with aniline or nitrosobenzene to form azobenzene or azoxybenzene and the unconverted aniline can also react with nitrosobenzene by condensation to form azobenzene, which can also be oxidized to form azoxybenzene ( ) . In order to further examine the catalytic properties, we have investigated the conversion for the oxidation of aniline and the products selectivity, using only Cu(NO3)2 as catalyst under the same reaction conditions. The result showed that the Cu(NO3)2 led to a much lower aniline conversion (about 12%) relative to the compound 1. The Cu(NO3)2 catalyst displayed curious behavior in terms of selectivity, leading to the preferentially formation of N-phenylformamide (a product from the formylation of aniline) probably due to the acidity of the reaction medium, and only traces of nitrobenzene . The results highlight the superior catalytic performance of compound 1 for aniline oxidation to azobenzene compared with the Cu(NO3)2 salt.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st085">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0190" view="all">A novel tetrameric ligand (<ce:bold>TBTP</ce:bold>) based on 1,2,3-triazoles obtained in a straightforward way by click chemistry reaction was synthetized and showed to be an effective ligand to obtain 1-D coordination polymers. We have obtained two crystalline solids (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) containing the TBTP ligand coordinated to Cu(II). The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized using acetonitrile as the only solvent, while the crystal of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was synthesized using a mixture of acetonitrile and water. From the analysis of X-ray diffraction of single crystals was observed that the different crystalline structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, present the same 1-D cationic chain. The Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion adopts a square planar geometry for coordinating with four triazole groups through the Cu<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond. The 1D coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, showed an antiferromagnetic behaviour attributed to the intra-chain magnetic coupling between the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion spins and the inter-chain dipolar interactions. The low intensity observed for the antiferromagnetic interaction is due to the high distance between each metal center. The synthesis of ligands containing triazole rings using the “Click Chemistry” tool shown to be promising for the development of new coordination polymers. New compounds containing different metal centers and shorter metal-metal distances are under investigation in order to form 2D and 3D coordination polymers with improved magnetical properties and promising catalytic properties, in which we have demonstrated that the 1-D polymer compound could be very active in the selective oxidation of aniline toward azobenzene under mild reaction conditions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel tetrameric ligand (TBTP) based on 1,2,3-triazoles obtained in a straightforward way by click chemistry reaction was synthetized and showed to be an effective ligand to obtain 1-D coordination polymers. We have obtained two crystalline solids (1 and 2) containing the TBTP ligand coordinated to Cu(II). The compound 1 was synthesized using acetonitrile as the only solvent, while the crystal of 2 was synthesized using a mixture of acetonitrile and water. From the analysis of X-ray diffraction of single crystals was observed that the different crystalline structures 1 and 2, present the same 1-D cationic chain. The Cu2+ ion adopts a square planar geometry for coordinating with four triazole groups through the CuN bond. The 1D coordination polymers 1 and 2, showed an antiferromagnetic behaviour attributed to the intra-chain magnetic coupling between the Cu2+ ion spins and the inter-chain dipolar interactions. The low intensity observed for the antiferromagnetic interaction is due to the high distance between each metal center. The synthesis of ligands containing triazole rings using the "Click Chemistry" tool shown to be promising for the development of new coordination polymers. New compounds containing different metal centers and shorter metal-metal distances are under investigation in order to form 2D and 3D coordination polymers with improved magnetical properties and promising catalytic properties, in which we have demonstrated that the 1-D polymer compound could be very active in the selective oxidation of aniline toward azobenzene under mild reaction conditions.

<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthetic procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:bold>Tetrakis(2-propinyloximethyl)methane</ce:bold>
 To the solution of pentaerythritol (1.087 g, 7.35 mmol) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (50 mL), cooled at 0 °C in argon atmosphere, sodium hydride 60% (1.787 g, 44.10 mmol) was added portionwise, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. Propargyl bromide (3.67 mL, 41.16 mmol) was added dropwise at 0 °C. After ten minutes, the temperature was increased until room temperature and the reaction was stirred for 24 h. Then, water (100 mL) was poured and the mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3x50 mL). Combined extracts were washed with brine (3x50 mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography (hexane:EtOAc 7:3, hexane:EtOAc 7:3, potassium permanganate solution as revealer) to furnish <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as a yellow solid (1.45 mg, 63%). FT-IR <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>: 3278, 2920, 2888, 2117, 1471, 1437, 1357, 1087, 906, 686. <ce:bold>Benzylazide</ce:bold>
 Benzyl bromide (1.44 g, 8.41 mmol) and sodium azide (4.39 g, 67.28 mmol) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (40 mL) was stirred at 60 °C, for 24 h. The reaction was followed by TLC, using anisaldehyde as revealer. The mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3 × 50 mL) and combined extracts were washed with brine (2 × 30 mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated, furnishing benzylazide as a light brown liquid (859 mg, 77%). <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR (CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 300 MHz): δ 4.37 (s, 2H), δ 7.44–7.37 (m, 5H). <ce:sup loc="post">13</ce:sup>C NMR (CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 75 MHz): δ 135.8; δ 129.22; δ 128.69; δ 128.61, δ 55.17.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">

A solution of copper(I) bromide (30.40 mg, 0.204 mmol in acetonitrile, 1.02 mL) was added to a solution of tris[(1-benzyl-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl]amine (TBTA) (131.56 mg, 0.244 mmol) in dichlorometane (0.61 mL). FITR (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3133, 3084, 2913, 2874, 1547, 1455, 1345, 1152, 1079, 1049, 754, 720.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st055">Catalytic oxidation of aniline</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The aniline oxidation reaction was conducted according to the procedure previously described . In a typical experiment, a mixture of 0.1 mL of aniline (SYNTH), 0.50 mL of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (30% (w/w), Sigma-Aldrich) 10 mg of catalyst and 3 mL of solvent (acetonitrile, SYNTH) was transferred to a 10 mL round-bottom flask connected to a septum-inlet Flask. This catalytic system was kept under stirring for 12 h at room-temperature. Upon completion, the reaction was quenched. Next, an aliquot of the reaction medium was then diluted in chloroform and injected in to the gas chromatograph for analysis. The analysis was performed on gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2010 Plus Tracera) connected to a Shimadzu SH-Rtx-5 capillary column and barrier discharge ionization detector (BID). Aniline conversion and product formation were quantified with the help of an external calibration curve, which was obtained by injecting authentic samples of known concentrations. Conversion of aniline was calculated by Eq. :<ce:display>

Synthetic procedures

 Tetrakis(2-propinyloximethyl)methane  To the solution of pentaerythritol (1.087g, 7.35mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (50mL), cooled at 0°C in argon atmosphere, sodium hydride 60% (1.787g, 44.10mmol) was added portionwise, and the mixture was stirred for 30min. Propargyl bromide (3.67mL, 41.16mmol) was added dropwise at 0°C. After ten minutes, the temperature was increased until room temperature and the reaction was stirred for 24h. Then, water (100mL) was poured and the mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3x50 mL). Combined extracts were washed with brine (3x50 mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated. The crude residue was purified by column chromatography (hexane:EtOAc 7:3, hexane:EtOAc 7:3, potassium permanganate solution as revealer) to furnish 3 as a yellow solid (1.45mg, 63%). FT-IR ν/cm-1: 3278, 2920, 2888, 2117, 1471, 1437, 1357, 1087, 906, 686. ESI-MS calculated for 3 C17H20O4Na: 311.1[M+Na]+; found 311.1.

 Benzylazide  Benzyl bromide (1.44g, 8.41mmol) and sodium azide (4.39g, 67.28mmol) in N,N-dimethylformamide (40mL) was stirred at 60°C, for 24h. The reaction was followed by TLC, using anisaldehyde as revealer. The mixture was extracted with diethyl ether (3×50mL) and combined extracts were washed with brine (2×30mL), dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate, filtered, and concentrated, furnishing benzylazide as a light brown liquid (859mg, 77%). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300MHz): δ 4.37 (s, 2H), δ 7.44-7.37 (m, 5H). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 75MHz): δ 135.8; δ 129.22; δ 128.69; δ 128.61, δ 55.17.

 Tetrameric ligand (TBTP) The core Tetrakis(2-propinyloximethyl)methane (317mg, 1.10mmol) and benzylazide (642mg, 4.83mmol) were dissolved in acetonitrile:water (1.83:1.02mL). A solution of copper(I) bromide (30.40mg, 0.204mmol in acetonitrile, 1.02mL) was added to a solution of tris[(1-benzyl-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl]amine (TBTA) (131.56mg, 0.244mmol) in dichlorometane (0.61mL). This mixture was added to the initial solution. The reaction was heated in a microwave apparatus for 20min at 60°C. Quadrasil MP resin was added to the mixture. After filtration, solvents were evaporated to provide the tetrameric ligand TBTP as a white solid (817mg, 91%). Elemental analysis (%) for C45H48O4N12: found (calculated) C 65.74 (65.84); H 6.02 (5.89); N 20.60 (20.47). FT-IR  ν /cm -1: 3110, 3062, 2915, 2871, 1497, 1456, 1326, 1125, 1083, 1050, 763, 716. 1H NMR (CDCl3, 500MHz): δ 3.40 (s, 8H), δ 4.50 (s, 8H), δ 5.52 (s, 8H), δ 7.20-7.40 (m, 20H), δ 7.55 (s, 4H). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 125MHz): δ 145.54; δ 135.27; δ 128.92; δ 128.46; δ 127.98; δ 122.64; δ 69.02; δ 64.84; δ 53.84; δ 45.11. ESI-MS calculated for C45H48O4N12Na: 843 [M+Na]+, found 843.3. Melting point: 105-109°C.

1-D coordination compounds

 [Cu(TBTP)][Cu(NO3)4] (1) The ligand TBTP (16.40mg, 0.02mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (3.0mL) at 45°C. Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (4.83mg, 0.02mmol) was dissolved in acetonitrile (1.0mL). Both solutions were mixed dropwise and the reaction was stirred for 15min at 45°C. The resulting solution was kept at room temperature and blue prismatic single crystals were obtained by slow evaporation of solvent. Crystals were filtered through centrifugation using Ultrafree-MC tubes (0.1μm) to furnish complex 1 (8.1mg, 34%). Elemental analysis (%) for C45H48Cu2N16O6: Found (calculated) C 45.22 (45.19); H 3.99 (4.05); N 18.78 (18.74). FITR (ν/cm-1); 3138, 3082, 2920, 2878, 1560, 1455, 1343, 1153, 1079, 1048, 755, 724.

 [Cu(TBTP)](NO3)2  (2). 4.83mg (0.02mmol) of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate dissolved in acetonitrile (1.0mL) and added dropwise to a solution of ligand TBTP (16.40mg, 0.02mmol) in acetonitrile (3.0mL). To this solution was added 0.8mL of water. The mixture was stirred for 15min at 45°C. The resulting solution obtained was allowed to slow evaporation for 48h at room temperature forming blue prismatic single crystals which were filtered through centrifugation using Ultrafree-MC tubes (0.1μm) to furnish the complex 2 (6.5mg, 32%). Elemental analysis (%) for C45H48CuN14O10: Found (calculated) C 53.74 (53.59); H 4.75 (4.80); N 19.71 (19.44). FITR (ν/cm-1): 3133, 3084, 2913, 2874, 1547, 1455, 1345, 1152, 1079, 1049, 754, 720.

Catalytic oxidation of aniline

The aniline oxidation reaction was conducted according to the procedure previously described . In a typical experiment, a mixture of 0.1mL of aniline (SYNTH), 0.50mL of H2O2 (30% (w/w), Sigma-Aldrich) 10mg of catalyst and 3mL of solvent (acetonitrile, SYNTH) was transferred to a 10mL round-bottom flask connected to a septum-inlet Flask. This catalytic system was kept under stirring for 12h at room-temperature. Upon completion, the reaction was quenched. Next, an aliquot of the reaction medium was then diluted in chloroform and injected in to the gas chromatograph for analysis. The analysis was performed on gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2010 Plus Tracera) connected to a Shimadzu SH-Rtx-5 capillary column and barrier discharge ionization detector (BID). Aniline conversion and product formation were quantified with the help of an external calibration curve, which was obtained by injecting authentic samples of known concentrations. Conversion of aniline was calculated by Eq. :  (1)   Conversion   ( % )   =    moles of reactant reacted   initial moles of reactant used   × 100

The Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> catalyst displayed curious behavior in terms of selectivity, leading to the preferentially formation of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-phenylformamide (a product from the formylation of aniline) probably due to the acidity of the reaction medium, and only traces of nitrobenzene . The similarity can be also emphasized by the dihedral angle between the least-squares planes through the two trans-triazole rings, presenting the value of 74.25° and 75.55 for 1 and 2, respectively. When we analyze the Cu…Cu distance occurring in each 1D-coordiantion polymer, in 2 is observed the Cu1…Cu1 separation of 8.860Å, while in the structure of 1 the Cu1..Cu1 distance is slightly shorter (8.630Å).

Magnetic properties

   shows the magnetic properties, in the form of the    χ M    T product vs T plot, for both compounds (1 and 2) in the temperature range of 2-300K [   χ M   being the molar magnetic susceptibility for two (1) or one (2) Cu(II) ion]. At room temperature, the    χ M    T product shows values of 0.835 and 0.410cm3 mol-1 K for (1) and (2) respectively. These values are in the range of those expected for copper(II) ions magnetically isolated. At low temperatures (T<20K) a very slight decrease of these values occurs, which can be attributed to the presence of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions. These plots can be perfectly reproduced by the Curie-Weiss Law , where N is Avogadro's number, β is the Bohr magneton, k is Boltzman's constant, S = ½, g is the Landé g-factor and θ is the Weiss constant .  (4)    χ M  =   N   β  2    g  2    3 k    T - θ      S    S + 1        

Best-fit parameters obtained through Eq.  were g=2.11(1) and θ=-0.110(2) K, for 1, and g=2.09(1) and θ=-0.050(1) K, for 2. EPR spectra are as expected for a spin doublet with axial symmetry (see the insets of ). The average values obtained from the magnetic susceptibility measurements for both compound are in full agreement with those observed in the EPR spectra.

Catalytic properties

In order to probe the catalytic activity of the synthesized 1-D coordination polymer, the complex 1 was used as catalyst for aniline oxidation reaction under mild conditions (room temperature, atmospheric pressure and using H2O2 as oxidizing agent). Previously, the reaction was conducted without catalyst under the same conditions. No appreciable aniline conversion was detected in this case. However, by using the coordination polymer, it could be observed that the compound 1 was very active ( ), practically promoting the complete conversion of aniline (91.9%). Regarding the reaction selectivity, compound 1 preferentially catalyzed the formation of azobenzene (45.9% of selectivity), with some concomitant formation of nitrosobenzene, nitrobenzene and azoxybenzene as secondary products. The phenylhydroxylamine production was not detected. This result indicates that phenylhydroxylamine oxidizes to nitrosobenzene and further to nitrobenzene. In the course of the reaction, however, intermediate phenylhydroxylamine can react with aniline or nitrosobenzene to form azobenzene or azoxybenzene and the unconverted aniline can also react with nitrosobenzene by condensation to form azobenzene, which can also be oxidized to form azoxybenzene ( ) . In order to further examine the catalytic properties, we have investigated the conversion for the oxidation of aniline and the products selectivity, using only Cu(NO3)2 as catalyst under the same reaction conditions. The result showed that the Cu(NO3)2 led to a much lower aniline conversion (about 12%) relative to the compound 1. The Cu(NO3)2 catalyst displayed curious behavior in terms of selectivity, leading to the preferentially formation of N-phenylformamide (a product from the formylation of aniline) probably due to the acidity of the reaction medium, and only traces of nitrobenzene . The results highlight the superior catalytic performance of compound 1 for aniline oxidation to azobenzene compared with the Cu(NO3)2 salt.

catalytic activity.condition: room temperature, atmospheric pressure and using H2O2 as oxidizing agent
